title: Quantum Random Access Codes for Boolean Functions

sections.related work: An nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹mğ‘›ğ‘maps-toğ‘šn\overset{p}{\mapsto}m (Q)RAC is an encoding of nğ‘›n bits into mğ‘šm (qu)bits such that any initial bit can be recovered with probability at least pğ‘p. This probability is the worst case success probability over all possible pairs (x,i)ğ‘¥ğ‘–(x,i) of input string xâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}nğ‘¥superscript11ğ‘›x\in\{-1,1\}^{n} and recoverable bit iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i\in\{1,\dots,n\}. Many different resources can be used during the encoding and decoding, e.g.Â private randomnessÂ (PR), shared randomnessÂ (SR), shared entanglement, and even super-quantum correlations like Popescu-Rohrlich boxesÂ . Regarding the classical RAC, Ambainis et al.Â  proved that there is no 2â€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹12ğ‘maps-to12\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 RAC (and 2mâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹msuperscript2ğ‘šğ‘maps-toğ‘š2^{m}\overset{p}{\mapsto}m RAC by extension) with PR and worst case success probability p>1/2ğ‘12p>1/2. On the other hand, Ambainis et al.Â [ref]5 showed that RACs with SR can achieve success probability p>1/2ğ‘12p>1/2. The optimal nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹1ğ‘›ğ‘maps-to1n\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 RAC with SR has success probability For a general number of encoded bits, Ambainis et al.Â  developed a RAC with PR using a specific code fromÂ  which matches their classical lower bound mâ‰¥(1âˆ’Hâ€‹(p))â€‹nğ‘š1ğ»ğ‘ğ‘›m\geq(1-H(p))n up to an additive logarithmic term, where Hâ€‹(p)=âˆ’pâ€‹log2â¡pâˆ’(1âˆ’p)â€‹log2â¡(1âˆ’p)ğ»ğ‘ğ‘subscript2ğ‘1ğ‘subscript21ğ‘H(p)=-p\log_{2}{p}-(1-p)\log_{2}(1-p) is the binary entropy function. There is an nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹mğ‘›ğ‘maps-toğ‘šn\overset{p}{\mapsto}m RAC with PR and mâ‰¤(1âˆ’Hâ€‹(p))â€‹n+7â€‹log2â¡nğ‘š1ğ»ğ‘ğ‘›7subscript2ğ‘›m\leq(1-H(p))n+7\log_{2}{n} for any p>12ğ‘12p>\frac{1}{2}. As for QRACs, Ambainis et al.Â  showed the existence of a 2â€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹12ğ‘maps-to12\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 QRAC with PR111Usually private randomness is already assumed in QRACs under the encoding onto density matrices. and p=12+12â€‹2â‰ˆ0.85ğ‘121220.85p=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}\approx 0.85, and the existence of a 3â€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹13ğ‘maps-to13\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 QRAC with PR and p=12+12â€‹3â‰ˆ0.79ğ‘121230.79p=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}\approx 0.79 (the second attributed to Chuang). Later Hayashi et al.Â  showed the impossibility of a 4â€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹14ğ‘maps-to14\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 QRAC (and 4mâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹msuperscript4ğ‘šğ‘maps-toğ‘š4^{m}\overset{p}{\mapsto}m QRAC by extension) with PR and success probability p>1/2ğ‘12p>1/2. Similarly to the classical case, Ambainis et al.Â [ref]5 showed that QRACs can also benefit from SR. There is an nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹1ğ‘›ğ‘maps-to1n\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 QRAC with SR and 222Ambainis et al.Â [ref]5 do not give the high order terms, but these can be calculated by following their procedure together withÂ [30, Equation 2.198]. The specific case of m=2ğ‘š2m=2 encoding qubits was explored inÂ   . For the general case of m>1ğ‘š1m>1, Iwama et al.Â  constructed an (4mâˆ’1)â€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹msuperscript4ğ‘š1ğ‘maps-toğ‘š(4^{m}-1)\overset{p}{\mapsto}m QRAC with PR and p=12+12â€‹(2mâˆ’1)â€‹2m+1ğ‘1212superscript2ğ‘š1superscript2ğ‘š1p=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2(2^{m}-1)\sqrt{2^{m}+1}} (such construction also works for all n<4mğ‘›superscript4ğ‘šn<4^{m}). On the other hand, Ambainis et al.Â  proved that if an nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹mğ‘›ğ‘maps-toğ‘šn\overset{p}{\mapsto}m QRAC with PR and p>1/2ğ‘12p>1/2 exists, then m=Î©â€‹(n/logâ¡n)ğ‘šÎ©ğ‘›ğ‘›m=\Omega(n/\log{n}), which was later improved to mâ‰¥(1âˆ’Hâ€‹(p))â€‹nğ‘š1ğ»ğ‘ğ‘›m\geq(1-H(p))n by NayakÂ 3, thus matching the same classical lower bound fromÂ . The idea of decoding a function of the initial bits instead of a single bit was already considered by Ben-Aroya, Regev and de WolfÂ  (who also considered recovering multiple bits rather than just one). More specifically, they defined an nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹mğ‘›ğ‘maps-toğ‘šn\overset{p}{\mapsto}m XORksubscriptXORğ‘˜\operatorname{XOR}_{k}-QRAC, where nğ‘›n bits are encoded into mğ‘šm qubits such that the parity of any kğ‘˜k initial bits can be recovered with success probability at leastÂ pğ‘p.333In their definition the success probability is the average over random kğ‘˜k-subsets and random inputs, which, in our context, is equivalent to using SR. Using their hypercontractive inequality for matrix-valued functions, they proved the following upper bound on the success probability. For any Î·>2â€‹lnâ¡2ğœ‚22\eta>2\ln{2} there is a constant CÎ·subscriptğ¶ğœ‚C_{\eta} such that, for any nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹mğ‘›ğ‘maps-toğ‘šn\overset{p}{\mapsto}m XORksubscriptXORğ‘˜\operatorname{XOR}_{k}-QRAC with SR and k=oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘›k=o(n), They conjectured that the factor Î·>2â€‹lnâ¡2ğœ‚22\eta>2\ln{2} can be dropped from the above bound, and thus extended to m/n>1/(2â€‹lnâ¡2)â‰ˆ0.72ğ‘šğ‘›1220.72m/n>1/(2\ln{2})\approx 0.72, although it might require a strengthening of their hypercontractive inequality. The use of shared entanglement in random access codes was first considered by KlauckÂ  . Here the encoding and decoding parties are allowed to use an arbitrary amount of shared entangled states (note that shared entanglement can be used to obtain both private and shared randomness). The figure of merit in this generalization is the relation between nğ‘›n, mğ‘šm and pğ‘p, while the amount of shared entanglement is not taken into account. KlauckÂ   considered an nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹mğ‘›ğ‘maps-toğ‘šn\overset{p}{\mapsto}m QRAC with shared entanglement and, by its equivalence to the quantum one-way communication complexity for the index function, proved the lower bound mâ‰¥(1âˆ’Hâ€‹(p))â€‹n/2ğ‘š1ğ»ğ‘ğ‘›2m\geq(1-H(p))n/2, similar to Nayakâ€™s bound. Later PawÅ‚owski and Å»ukowskiÂ 8 coined the term entanglement-assisted random access code (EARAC), which is a RAC with shared entanglement, and studied the case when m=1ğ‘š1m=1, giving protocols with better decoding probabilities compared to the usual nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹1ğ‘›ğ‘maps-to1n\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 QRAC with SR. Recently TÄƒnÄƒsescu et al.Â  expanded the idea of nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹1ğ‘›ğ‘maps-to1n\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 EARACs to recovering an initial bit under a specific request distribution. The optimal nâ€‹â†¦ğ‘â€‹1ğ‘›ğ‘maps-to1n\overset{p}{\mapsto}1 EARAC with SR has success probability The idea of (Q)RAC was generalized in other ways, e.g.Â parity-obliviousÂ    and multipartyÂ  versions, encoding on dğ‘‘d-valued qubits (qudits)Â [ref]6    , a wider range of information retrieval tasksÂ  and a connection to Popescu-Rohrlich boxes. It was shownÂ  that a Popescu-Rohrlich box can simulate a RAC by means of just one bit of communication, while inÂ  the converse was proven. An object called racboxÂ  was defined, which is a box that implements a RAC when supported with one bit of communication, and it was shown that a non-signaling racbox is equivalent to a Popescu-Rohrlich box. A quantum version of a racbox was later proposed inÂ . Finally, we mention that RACs were also studied within â€œtheoriesâ€ that violate the uncertainty relation for anti-commuting observables and present stronger-than-quantum correlationsÂ .
